top_ideas.description: Kierkegaard asserted that truth is not merely objective fact but must be subjectively appropriated. For matters of existence, especially religious belief, passionate inward commitment is what makes something true for the individual.

Kierkegaard argued that religious belief requires a 'leap of faith'—an irrational but necessary commitment to the divine that cannot be justified by reason alone. Faith transcends evidence and is deeply personal.

He described three existential stages of life: the aesthetic (pursuit of pleasure), the ethical (commitment to duty and responsibility), and the religious (authentic faith). True selfhood is reached only in the religious stage.

Despair is the sickness of the self that comes from not being in right relation with God. It arises from not willing to be oneself or from willing to be something other than what one is created to be.

top_ideas.idea: Anxiety as a Condition of Freedom
top_ideas.description: Kierkegaard viewed anxiety (angst) as the dizziness of freedom—the awareness of one’s capacity to choose. It is both a burden and a precondition for authentic existence.

Kierkegaard emphasized the paradoxical nature of Christian faith, especially belief in the incarnation. Faith is not rational but is held in tension with reason—what he called the 'offense of Christianity.'

The 'knight of faith' is the individual who, after resigning everything finite, regains it all again through faith. This figure lives fully in the finite world while being in absolute relation to the infinite.

Kierkegaard used pseudonyms and fictional authors to express various existential perspectives. This strategy of 'indirect communication' was designed to make the reader confront the truth personally rather than receive it dogmatically.

Kierkegaard believed true Christianity is radically offensive to reason and social norms. The paradox of God becoming man (Christ) challenges all worldly understanding and calls for total inward transformation.
The goal of human life is to become a true self in relationship with God. This requires confronting despair, accepting one’s finitude and freedom, and living authentically in faith.
